description:
Grade II listed building from 1889 with diverse historical functions - now functioning as Theatre venue and dance studios.
A more recent remodelling and additional dance studios has made the complex a bright and contemporary venue.
facilities: Photography is not permitted on site

factsheet.heading: The Place
paragraphs: The Place is a creative powerhouse for dance development, in the heart of London. One of Europe’s most exciting, innovative dance spaces, where artists from all over the world come to push creative boundaries, to experiment and to perform outstanding new work for audiences who expect to be surprised, inspired and delighted. The Place is home to London Contemporary Dance School, a 288 seat theatre auditorium, an extensive range of classes, courses and participatory opportunities for adults and young people, and professional development programmes for artists.

factsheet.heading: Flaxman Terrace (Main entrance and reception)
paragraphs:
This newer part of the building complex was extensively refurbished between 1999-2001, following a design by Allies and Morrison. The designers worked with The Place to create a building truly fit for dance. The guiding design ideas were Space, Light, Durability and Flexibility.
We will highlight the different departments and programmes currently run by The Place, and discuss the history of the organisation.

factsheet.heading: Duke's Road (Theatre entrance and box office)
paragraphs:
On Duke's Road we find the original building where The Place took root in 1969. 
This building was designed by architect Sir Robert Edis, and completed in 1888-89 to house the Artists’ Rifles: a paramilitary volunteer group comprised of painters, musicians, actors etc. The facade and some interior features are Grade II listed, as they are exemplary of the Victorian Aesthetic Movement and later Queen Anne style.
Now, it houses the Robin Howard Dance Theatre auditorium, seating close to 300 audience members.
